text:
Saw this KitKat ad from last year and it still hits:

‚ÄúThe break you need after 7 Zoom calls.‚Äù

So simple.
So true.
So brutal.

It reminded me of a Microsoft study I came across around the same time ‚Äî and honestly, it stuck with me.

They ran fMRI + EEG scans on people with and without meeting breaks.

What they found?

Back-to-back meetings are one of the worst things you can do for your brain.

Here‚Äôs why breaks aren‚Äôt optional ‚Äî they‚Äôre essential:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Stress Reset: Even short meditation breaks prevent stress buildup.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Better Engagement: Breaks = better frontal alpha asymmetry = more present participants.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Sharper Focus: Beta waves stay balanced ‚Üí no burnout ‚Üí better thinking.
4Ô∏è‚É£ Well-being Wins: Especially critical in remote/hybrid setups.

So if you‚Äôre on call #6 today‚Ä¶

üì£ Take. That. Break.
‚ôª Repost if you needed this reminder too.
üç´ Bonus points if it‚Äôs a KitKat

text:
As a 2-times $1M founder, 

These are the 5 Things I Wish I'd Known Sooner:

üéØ Nobody Cares About Your Cool Solution
Let's be honest - I spent way too long being excited about features nobody asked for. People don't buy "nice-to-haves" - they buy "need-to-haves" that make their problems go away. How painful is the problem that you are solving?

üîç Get Picky About Who You Serve
I wasted months marketing to the wrong audience and burned cash and time through the process before getting it right. Find your ICP and refine it relentlessly until it's laser-precise. Don't even think about running ads until you've nailed exactly who you're talking to and confirmed they actually want what you're selling.

üå± Fish Where The Fish Are Biting
Look, some prospects are ready to buy now, and some will never be ready. I wasted so much time on the wrong people! Focus on high-intent channels where you can grab the low-hanging fruit. One good customer who's ready to buy beats ten who "might be interested someday."

‚è±Ô∏è Your Time Is Worth More Than You Think
This was a game-changer for me: before jumping into any task, I ask myself, "Can I automate this? Can someone else do this?" If you're doing $10/hour work when you could be doing $1,000/hour work, you're leaving money on the table.

ü§ñ AI Won't Save You (But It Can Help)
I got caught up in the AI hype too, buying tools I barely used, it‚Äôs not the answer to every question. Use AI to automate workflows and manual work to make more of your time. That's how I started building Fuelgrowth - to strike that balance. We use AI to get deep insights impossible for us to derive and to make efficient workflows, but we know it's the human touch that really makes marketing work. No robot can replace good content.

On a side note do you want to see what you're missing? My team is planning to offer a FREE Performance Review to a few companies that reach out to us. We combine AI insights with human expertise to analyse everything from details as minute as audio choices to even your influencer selection. We'll show you exactly how to make every marketing dollar count. Comment ‚ÄòSUPERADS‚Äô below or connect with me for a conversation

Have a Good day!üòä

Trump just saved TikTok in the US or did he ? But what happens next?

The recent 13-hour TikTok ban caused major uncertainty. 

And while the app is back, to the great relief of creators, smes, entrepreneurs and many advertisers, big questions remain:

 ‚Ä¢ Could this mean more legal challenges ahead for TikTok?

 ‚Ä¢ How should brands and creators prepare for future disruptions?

 ‚Ä¢ What does this mean for the future of social commerce?

That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre hosting a free webinar: "TikTok‚Äôs Quick Ban Saga: Insights, Opportunities, and the Future of Social Media Ads"

When? January 28th at 11 AM EST

Join us as I,  Xavier de Baillenx, Evan Weber, and TikToker @neatmckinley break it all down.

Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôll cover:

1. The legal implications of the ban and restoration: What might happen next?

2. Why TikTok remains a critical platform for brands, supported by key stats.

3. How TikTok‚Äôs content-first strategy is reshaping ads and social media.

4. The rise of TikTok Shop and livestream commerce, and their impact on e-commerce.

This is your chance to get ahead of the trends and understand how to navigate this evolving landscape.

text:
Late Post! I was in Manila in September where I was invited to speak about "AI beauty revolution" by the Chamber of cosmetics industry in the Philippines. The Panel had a great mix of legal, data science and AI research experts. 

The discussion ranged from data security concerns, vertical AI use-cases for businesses, legal implications from widespread AI use and put simply how do we get started with incorporating AI in our day to day activities at work. 

Few takeaways from the discussion : 
1) Be open to adopting AI in your workflows to stay ahead of the market, look at what your global counterparts are doing or what your local competitors are doing and keep an open mind about the potential. 
2) Start small with AI use them for your daily communications with the customer, customer support automation,  employee knowledge centres and process automations. 
3) Keep an eye on the public and government policies on AI and how they evolve with time but don't let that slow your AI adoption. 
4) Incentivise and encourage your employees to use AI for daily tasks rather than making it a barrier, open up strategic roles to use AI and certain roles where there are confidential data keep strict policies to avoid data leaks. 
5) Various AI applications in providing a personalised experience to consumers at every touchpoint from Social media to website checkout to support.

Over all it was so encouraging to see so many successful entrepreneurs still looking to learn, evolve and keep pace with changing times. 

Many thanks to the fellow panelists who shared great insights and knowledge Guita Gopalan Alex Austria Kyle Patrick Bartido Ralph Vincent Regalado and to Diego Buenaflor for putting this together.

text:
Over the past few weeks, the team at Fuelgrowth has been heads-down, laser-focused on execution, customer obsession, and building serious momentum.

üåç As a founder building in the generative AI space across Asia, I‚Äôve had the opportunity to meet customers, partners, and investors across Singapore, Delhi NCR, and Bangalore. These conversations have provided valuable insights, and I wanted to share a few key patterns we‚Äôve observed in the market:

1. Early AI adopters are wary:
Many early adopters have faced challenges in realizing the promised value of AI. This has created skepticism, as tools haven‚Äôt consistently outperformed human capabilities across job functions. üö´

2. Unrealistic expectations slow adoption:
Buyers often expect AI to deliver end-to-end solutions, without requiring incremental user input. This mindset has delayed AI adoption, as stakeholders hesitate to engage with tools that still require human involvement. üîÑ

3. Enterprises are stuck in pilot mode:
While internal mandates for AI-driven cost optimization and growth exist, internal champions lack conviction. Many enterprises remain in the pilot phase, waiting for proven use cases before fully committing. ‚è≥

4. Midmarket and growth-oriented firms lead the way:
There‚Äôs a silver lining: midmarket and fast-growing companies are actively experimenting with AI use cases. These early adopters are willing to be patient, collaborate, and become your initial champions. For founders like myself, these are the partnerships that fuel early-stage growth. üí°

5. Offering ‚ÄúAI Outcomes as a Service‚Äù may be the answer:
Another path is positioning yourself as an agency, offering ‚Äúoutcome as a service‚Äù by using your product to automate internal processes and building case studies that showcase profitable results. This can help reduce the risk/reward ratio for clients and accelerate market adoption. üìà

The generative AI space is full of opportunity, but founders need to be strategic about how they approach the market. I‚Äôm eager to connect with fellow founders, investors, and enablers who are passionate about shaping the future of AI.
Let‚Äôs build together! ü§ù #AI #GenerativeAI #Entrepreneurship #Tech #Startup #AsiaTech #Innovation #Growth

text:
Static Ads Are Making a Comeback!

Yes, you heard me right.

Over the past three months, collaborating with various brands and agencies has revealed an intriguing insight that challenges the current market playbooks.

Our data and performance analysis comparing UGC reels and static ads clearly show a winner.

If you're a brand looking to leverage social media platforms to boost engagement across your funnel, static creatives must be part of your content strategy. Here are three compelling reasons why:

Reel Fatigue: Attention spans are dwindling, and users are becoming more selective about the content they consume. Static ads offer a refreshing change.

Cost and Authenticity Issues with UGC: User-generated content is becoming
increasingly expensive. Users are savvy and can spot a sales pitch a mile away. Brands need to push more authentic data through UGC to stand out.

Message Clarity: Static ads allow brands to convey their message quickly and clearly as users scroll. Well-designed static ads, when intelligently positioned and targeted, drive better results.

And the most crucial reason:

Efficiency in Performance Marketing: Today's performance marketing thrives on rapid iterations and A/B testing. Static ads are cheaper and quicker to produce, allowing performance marketers to experiment more freely and optimize data-backed campaigns for better outcomes.

If you're a marketer, brand owner, content/brand head, or P&L owner, and this resonates with you‚Äîor if you have contrarian views‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear from you.

#Content #PerformanceMarketing #AI #DTC #Growth

For the past few months, we've been heads down, laser-focused on crafting cutting-edge solution for larger enterprises. But let me tell you, the journey has been anything but ordinary. We've had countless eye-opening conversations with potential users spanning SMEs to midmarket and enterprises, and the response has been phenomenal! üåü

Sharing some key takeaways that have been brewing in my mind:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Bold Conversations from Day One: Don't underestimate the power of engaging with enterprise and large organizations right from the get-go. Sometimes, the need for what you're building in these behemoths is far greater than you might anticipate. While SMEs are more accessible for conversations, it's often the big players who truly grasp the value of innovation.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Niche Focus, Stellar Solutions: Conversations with larger enterprises allow you to zero in on a niche and craft state-of-the-art solutions tailored to specific challenges. This focus breeds innovation and sets you apart in the market.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Crystal-Clear Messaging: Engaging with big players forces you to refine your messaging and positioning in the market. Being precise and clear becomes paramount, which ultimately benefits your entire brand identity.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Timing is Key: Navigating enterprise sales cycles, POCs, and sealing those game-changing deals alongside building your product is a marathon, not a sprint. It's crucial to tread carefully, leveraging feedback from fellow operators in the market to ensure your journey is a successful one.

Our journey at Fuelgrowth.ai is just getting started, and I'm thrilled to embark on this adventure alongside each of you. Let's keep the conversation going! üí¨

üìà Delhi/NCR stands tall as the beating heart of India's DTC market. While other cities may be all about Fintech, AI, SaaS and Devtools, here, we're all about DTC strategies, GTMs, scaling, and expansion.

üåü With a market this ripe for disruption, launching a DTC business here is a no-brainer! The sheer size of the market means you're automatically tapping into over 50%+ of India's population when you address its needs.

text:
How do visual cues influence your perception of a brand? üé®üëÅÔ∏è

Let's discuss and decode the language of marketing together!

Take, for instance, the captivating Febreze advertisement titled "Odour Chart" design by Procter & Gamble

At first glance, it may seem like a simple depiction of cheese, onion, and egg ‚Äì yet beneath the surface lies a complex interplay of semiotic elements.

In this ad, the use of these common household items transcends their literal meanings. They serve as powerful symbols, evoking not only the sensation of odor but also triggering memories and emotions associated with unpleasant smells. üå¨Ô∏èüí°

Through this clever manipulation of visual cues, Febreze subtly communicates its message of odor elimination without uttering a single word.

This ingenious utilization of semiotics underscores the profound impact that visual stimuli can have on brand perception. üí≠‚ú®

By tapping into our subconscious associations, advertisers can craft narratives that resonate deeply with consumers.

Let's infuse some semiotic magic into your advertising strategy. Try Fuelgrowth's Fuego now! üî•

#creative #marketing #advertising #febreze #creativecampaigns #ads #aiads

text:
As the world is still digesting all the updates Sam Altman announced earlier this week https://lnkd.in/gCZarrKc.  

Here are some of my initial thoughts : 

‚≠ê Wrappers on top of chatGPT with horizontal usecases and no data moat will all be eaten up by OpenAI eventually. All these usecases will eventually have a single interface that is chatGPT. 

‚≠ê Infrastructure and guardrails are safe and is still a good space to build in but based on what I have seen in the last 3-4 months everyone who initially wanted to build LLMs at the start of the year is now building the Infra layer - unless you can distribute and scale fast the space is heating up super quick. 

‚≠ê Vertical AI usecases with deep expertise and data moats will have winners faster than the infra layers which is waiting for winners to evolve in this space. If you peel few layers there are diamonds to unearth here and clear differentiations to build similar to how people have built products on Shopify app stores and other platforms, we will see big moves and winners in this space. 

‚≠ê OpenAI Appstore is a game changer and will only increase AI adoption incrementally. It will be a key distribution channel for AI apps moving forward. 

If you are not building in AI today, it still early days and not too late. AI is changing how humans work fundamentally and job descriptions in the near future will look very different! 

What are your takeaways and thoughts on what's next ? Does this change your AI strategy ? 

#ai #openai #chatgpt #gpt #openaidevday

text:
My interactions with DTC/agency operators and founders over the last 1 year has thrown light on some interesting observations on the what is happening in the DTC market. 

1)  There is very little differentiation on product these days hence competition for keywords is huge. 
2) ROAS  has been going down while CAC is increasing leading to brands and agencies fight it out to retain their market share instead of growing. 
3) Profitability at very early stages of brand building is now the norm which is also a pressure point for marketers and agencies.  Reasons : lesser venture money to burn and current market sentiments. 
4) Gone are the days where you could rely on performance marketing to be a differentiator. Every DTC brand has access to an agency/operator who knows performance marketing and there is very little moat here. 
5) Creatives is where the differentiation lies today. Every DTC brand is a now a content creation or a story telling house. The budgets for and Qty of creatives being churned out is increasing every day. 

Key learnings - Measure your creatives performances closely, automating your creative and performance marketing workflows will help brands reduce CAC and also improve ROAS. 

If you are a DTC founder, enabler or agency operator,  I would love to hear your thoughts on how you are navigating today's climate while building brands. 


#dtcmarketing #creative #contentmarketing #performancemarketing #dtcbrands

text:
üöÄ What We Look for in Startups at LvlUp Ventures üöÄ
(From the investor‚Äôs perspective)

At LvlUp Ventures, we back Seed-stage startups that are bold enough to think differently‚Äîand scrappy enough to make it happen.

Here‚Äôs what stands out to us when reviewing new opportunities:

‚úÖ Clear Problem & Unique Insight
Startups that truly understand the pain point they're solving and bring a fresh, founder-led perspective to the table.

‚úÖ Early Signs of Traction
This doesn't have to be sky-high revenue‚Äîbut strong signals like user retention, organic growth, partnerships or early sales channels working well.

‚úÖ A Sharp, Coachable Team
We love founders who are relentless and receptive. You're the expert in your domain‚Äîbut open to strategic collaboration.

‚úÖ Capital Efficiency
We‚Äôre big believers in doing more with less. Efficient execution and thoughtful resource allocation go a long way in this market.

‚úÖ Platform Potential
Can this product evolve into something bigger? We get excited by businesses with real ecosystem or category-defining potential.

Our team rolls up its sleeves post-investment‚Äîwe don‚Äôt just write checks, we help you grow through partnerships, channel support, and deep founder-in-residence experience.

If you're building something bold, we‚Äôd love to hear from you.

text:
üöÄ Why 2025 Might Be the Best Time in a Decade to Build a CPG Brand

With all the talk about rising costs, tighter capital, and DTC struggles‚Äîit might seem like the odds are stacked against emerging CPG brands. But under the surface, there's something exciting happening:

üîπ Retail buyers are hungry for innovative indie products that build loyalty and drive growth in a saturated aisle.
üîπ Strategic acquirers are back‚Äî2024 saw a ~20% YoY increase in M&A activity in food & beverage, especially in better-for-you and premium segments.
üîπ Community-led brands are thriving on platforms like TikTok, where 67% of Gen Z say they discover new CPG products.
üîπ Capital is still flowing, but it‚Äôs flowing smarter‚Äîinvestors are favoring capital-efficient operators with strong gross margins and clear paths to profitability.

üí° If you‚Äôre a founder building with a focus on retail strategy, product velocity, and community, you might be more ‚ÄúVC-backable‚Äù than you think.

‚ú® The CPG playbook has changed‚Äîbut for those who adapt, it might just be the best time to build.

text:
üö® Startups, VCs, and the Tariff Tension: What Now? üö®

President Trump‚Äôs newly reimposed tariffs are shaking markets, prompting a deeper question: What does this mean for startups and venture capital?

üìâ The Bad News:

Nasdaq is rattled ‚Äî with tech giants like NVIDIA and Tesla dropping double digits.

Klarna and StubHub postponed IPOs due to valuation pressure and uncertainty.

VCs are jittery. Theory Ventures' Tomasz Tunguz warned of a funding slowdown: ‚ÄúNo exits = no returns = no new funds.‚Äù

üìà The (Possible) Silver Lining:

Some sectors ‚Äî like #AI ‚Äî are seeing more investor attention. Andreessen Horowitz is reportedly raising a $20B megafund focused on U.S. growth-stage AI.

Multinational giants like TSMC, Intel Corporation, and Samsung Electronics have committed to pouring hundreds of billions of dollars into U.S.-based fabs and advanced manufacturing, potentially creating downstream opportunities for startups in #semiconductors, #robotics, #cleantech, and #logistics.

Tariff-induced instability might spur innovation, local #manufacturing, and startup diversification ‚Äî long-term positives for resilient founders.

üí¨ But here‚Äôs the real question: Are these tariffs a bargaining chip? Will we see them lifted or selectively reduced as leverage in future negotiations ‚Äî especially with key allies and trade partners? Could this be temporary noise, or the start of a prolonged recalibration of the global startup landscape?

#startups #venturecapital #trump #tariffs #IPO #VCfunding #AI #a16z #economy #innovation #vc #startup

text:
The ‚Äúfriends & family‚Äù round is a myth for most founders üò≤ 

No one talks enough about how hard it is to raise at the Pre-Seed and Seed stage when:

You don‚Äôt come from Stanford or Harvard
You don‚Äôt have a wealthy network
Your deck isn‚Äôt getting replies
And your traction is "early... but promising"

Yet somehow, you're expected to raise hundreds of thousands of dollars to build your MVP, grow your team, or just buy time to focus.

Here‚Äôs the truth: Fundraising at this stage isn‚Äôt just hard ‚Äî it‚Äôs opaque, inefficient, and often biased toward founders with connections, not capability.

We're combating this at LvlUp Ventures.

Our mission is simple: help great founders raise capital faster ‚Äî not because of who they know, but because of what they‚Äôre building.

We work with 15+ funding partners who actively invest in Pre-Seed and Seed rounds. We don‚Äôt charge founders a dime. We make warm intros, host investor events, and even help refine your materials if needed.

If you‚Äôre raising ‚Äî or thinking about it ‚Äî apply to our network. One app = exposure to dozens of investors.

text:
Founders keep telling me they‚Äôre ‚Äútoo early‚Äù for VCs üëÄ 

But more often than not, it‚Äôs not the stage that‚Äôs the problem ‚Äî it‚Äôs the story.

Investors don‚Äôt need millions in revenue.
We need to believe you‚Äôre the one to build something big.

When Airbnb was pitching, most investors passed.
The idea sounded niche. Couch-surfing for conferences? Really?

But they reframed it:
‚ÄúPeople are already doing this ‚Äî they‚Äôre just doing it in untrustworthy, fragmented ways. We‚Äôre building the trusted platform.‚Äù

They showed a vision that was WAY bigger than a few air mattresses.
They made the early traction feel inevitable.
They made the pain point obvious.

Suddenly, the ‚Äútoo early‚Äù startup became a rocketship üöÄ 

Here‚Äôs the truth:
You‚Äôre not too early.
You just haven‚Äôt told a story that makes your future feel inevitable.

If you‚Äôre a founder in that zone, I want to hear your pitch.
Even if you only have 20 users.

text:
AI is transforming workplace productivity by automating time-consuming and repetitive tasks, enabling teams to focus on higher-value activities. From data entry and report generation to drafting business documents and automating quality control in manufacturing, AI tools are streamlining workflows and saving time. This technology isn‚Äôt about replacing jobs but enhancing them‚Äîfreeing up employees to prioritize creativity, emotional intelligence, and strategic decision-making. Our fund actively invests in innovative AI solutions driving this shift, such as intelligent project management tools, AI-powered assistants, and automation platforms, as we see tremendous potential in supporting technologies that redefine efficiency and collaboration across industries.

text:
The future of AI and National Artificial Intelligence Association members‚Äô influence on it:

In my view, Artificial Intelligence is an almost limitless technology which, within the next three to five years will have the ability to entirely revolutionize the way we live and work. 

This is already proving to be the case, with large enterprises instituting hiring freezes on new talent due to the efficiencies of AI, and startups in our LvlUp Ventures portfolio creating entire platforms in days with zero software developers.

Within the next three years, I believe that AI will put us at an inflection point including such questions as: do we let AI have the capability to soon replace the majority of the workforce? Do we allow AI access sensitive to data for medical treatment development? Do we permit AI to deeply assist in war fighting?

People & governments around the world will be faced with the need to make decisions including on the issues above.

Currently, the Trump administration is rightfully advocating for strong investment & development in AI. That is largely due to the promise it contains for global competitiveness and the American economy. In just a couple of years, that will likely be a very different situation, as AI advancements will set the stage for the loss of potential jobs, cyber & biological threats, and more.

The National Artificial Intelligence Association, quickly becoming one of the largest technology coalitions in the country, is primed to ensure that the American people, government, and the world at large are able to make the right decisions before, during, and after these times in order to unleash American ingenuity and decide on what the ‚Äúfine line‚Äù is for Artificial Intellifence and its impact on society: limited or limitless integration; work or home; unfettered growth; or an entirely different approach.

#AI #technology #regulation #US #Globe

text:
The National Artificial Intelligence Association (NAIA) has been formed.

The NAIA is a non-profit trade association based in Washington, D.C., aiming to promote innovation and global competitiveness for American AI startups and companies.

Aaron Golbin, Co-Chair of NAIA, said that it's important for AI companies to have a voice in Washington as new policies are discussed.

The association offers free and paid memberships and will work with policymakers to ensure AI regulations don't hinder U.S. leadership in AI.

Read more: https://lnkd.in/eZWFcStJ

#ai #artificialintelligence
relative_time: 3 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
author_headline: 507 followers

text:
I am very proud to announce the launch of the National Artificial Intelligence Association (thenaia.org) this morning, and my role as Co-Founder and Co-Chair.

NAIA has a single, powerful mission: to ensure unparalleled innovation, opportunities, and global competitiveness for American startups and enterprises building in AI. The trade association will be the leading voice for the AI industry in Washington, already garnering the support of many on the Hill.

As the 119th Congress and the new Trump Administration tackle numerous policy issues related to the rapid application of artificial intelligence to a broad number of industries, it will be key that AI companies have a voice at the table. 

NAIA will work with our policy makers in Washington and on the State governments level to ensure that AI-related regulations do not impede keeping our country in the important global leadership position.

Memberships are now open, join us today to help ensure American leadership in AI ‚Äî and the success of our innovation economy.

I‚Äôm pleased to be working alongside political veterans & experts including Ron Wright, Caleb Max, and Tim Parrish. NAIA is also partnered with LvlUp Ventures, where I serve as Managing Partner, to provide access to NAIA to the thousands of startups applying to the firm annually.

Learn more: https://lnkd.in/eutf6TyK

üåü Portfolio Company Spotlight: Ascendia AI üåü

üöÄ Revolutionizing Mental Health Diagnostics: Using proprietary, AI-powered speech analysis, Ascendia AI transforms how mental health disorders are detected and managed. In just 5 minutes, their non-invasive evaluation analyzes 50+ vocal biomarkers, rigorously validated by over 30 years of research. Trained on a robust dataset of 17,000 clinical hours, this technology provides precise assessments across the DSM-5 spectrum, identifying primary, secondary, and even subclinical conditions for early intervention.

üí° Why It Matters: Mental health care lags 24% behind physical health care in treatment efficacy. Ascendia AI bridges this gap by empowering care providers across all disciplines‚Äînot just mental health professionals‚Äîwith data-driven tools that enhance early detection, personalized treatment, and ongoing progress tracking.

üìà Game-Changing Integration: Ascendia AI seamlessly integrates into existing systems, elevating care standards across organizations and platforms. Their approach sets a new benchmark for precision and personalization in mental healthcare, driving better outcomes for patients worldwide.

We‚Äôre excited to support Ascendia AI on their mission to revolutionize mental health diagnostics and care!

https://ascendia.ai/

text:
Introducing Hello Near Me
Over a decade of travelling together (and we are still married!).
20+ countries and counting.
Hundreds of amazing local experiences.¬†
Thousands of hours searching and countless local recommendations.

No matter your destination, the experience is always the same.
It‚Äôs the locals that make travelling so rewarding.

From the welcoming hotel concierge to the hospitable Airbnb host, from the timeless flavors of a family-owned eatery to the young upstart baker crafting a fresh take out of old recipes.

The excitement of a sports game with tens of thousands of local fans or the thrill of discovering an upcoming band playing at the back of the dive bar, with 30 other locals that were mostly there for the hot wings challenge! (which I reckon I could have won).

We are on a mission to celebrate these local experiences and connect as many travellers as possible to them.

So next time you travel, go and say hello.
Join us at hellonearme.com

If you are a hotel, Airbnb host or local business that wants to elevate the traveller's experience.
Please reach out.

text:
BIG TECH‚ÄôS AI BETS - are we back on (AI) track?

"Big tech companies ‚Äî¬†Alphabet¬†(Google),¬†Amazon,¬†Apple,¬†Meta,¬†Microsoft, and¬†Nvidia¬†‚Äî earned nearly $2T in aggregate revenue in 2024, up 15% from 2023. 

They already dwarf the private tech sector ‚Äî surpassing the¬†combined value of all 1,200+ unicorns¬†by a factor of 3 ‚Äî and after a period of layoffs, they‚Äôre back to hiring, with 2024 headcount growing an average of 7% YoY.

Now, they‚Äôre betting big on AI to power their next growth phase."

They are expected to spend over $320 billion on AI infrastructure in 2025. This is a big jump from $246 billion in 2024.

Here are some key points:
‚û°Ô∏è Massive Investments: Amazon plans to spend $100 billion, followed by Microsoft with $80 billion and Google with $75 billion. Most of this money is going into data centers to support AI growth.
‚û°Ô∏è AI and Cloud: AI is driving cloud services forward. Microsoft Azure grew by 31% last year, and Google Cloud is focusing on security to win more business customers.
‚û°Ô∏è Acquisitions Are Back: After a slowdown, big companies are buying again. Alphabet‚Äôs $33 billion deal for Wiz shows how important AI-focused acquisitions have become. Nvidia is also leading in funding AI startups.
‚û°Ô∏è New Markets: Companies are exploring areas like humanoid robots and general-purpose AI agents that could change industries.

AI is driving big tech's investments and hiring has ramped up again. 

Have we surpassed the AI trough of disillusionment? What do you think?

text:
Yesterday, I learned I‚Äòm living in another reality.

Caught in an AI bubble. Hunting for the next big leap to transform traditional teams into AI-augmented teams and further push towards agentic AI process automation.

However, I learned valuable lessons by attending the BVMW trade show, ‚ÄúFuture of SMEs,‚Äù and talking to several businesses, including real estate, construction, hotels, manufacturing, public administration, etc.

Something I learned in AdTech back then as well.

Most people and businesses operate without the drive of curiosity, innovation, and a growth mindset. 

They remain confined within their daily routines. 

Their established practices create a rigid corporate culture. 

There is a strong resistance to change, akin to a corporate immune system that rejects new ideas.

To be at the forefront of innovation is to anticipate the future consistently. 

The journey from the inception of a new trend, feature, or product to widespread adoption is often lengthy and fraught with challenges.

No one I talked to uses a Business AI, even when I described it as a personal ChatGPT for your company files. One company used Co-Pilot, and another one is currently testing ChatGPT. 

The whole market is still at step 1, while I expected it to be at least at step 3 (RAG at scale). 

But I‚Äôm living in another reality. 

We all live in our bubble‚Ä¶

Agree?

text:
No progress without (good) debates. 

We need to debate, including the one about AI. And we need to have different opinions.

On the one hand, there are those who see the potential, the positive benefits and the world-changing effects.

On the other side are those who are worried and have fears and concerns. 

There are always two sides to the same coin. It's what is called the principle of polarity. 

Black and white, yes and no, agree and disagree.

I belong to the group of visionaries, positive thinkers, curious, and sometimes also naive.

But I am less on the technical side and more on the humanistic side of AI. Does that sound counterintuitive? 

Let me explain! To me, AI, if used correctly, will bring two things to lift human potential: 

ùüè. ùêñùêû ùê∞ùê¢ùê•ùê• ùêõùêû ùê¶ùê®ùê´ùêû ùê¢ùêß ùêüùê•ùê®ùê∞
The challenge-skills balance is a key trigger for experiencing flow. It describes the state in which the demands of a task slightly exceed a person's abilities. If the challenge is too great, anxiety can arise, while boredom sets in if the challenge is too low. Flow occurs in an area known as the ‚Äòflow channel‚Äô and lies between these two extremes. This means that through working and living alongside AI, we will experience more flow.¬†Repetitive and mundane tasks can be handed over, and complicated tasks and complex questions can be solved more easily.

ùüê. ùêÜùêûùêßùêÄùêà ùê∞ùê¢ùê•ùê• ùê¶ùêöùê§ùêû ùêÆùê¨ ùêõùêûùê≠ùê≠ùêûùê´ ùê≠ùê°ùê¢ùêßùê§ùêûùê´ùê¨
Now that we have an omnipotent assistant whom we can ask, we must rethink our thinking. We need to become more curious again. It's not about advising AI; it is about asking the right questions and thinking in the correct pattern. We need to ask ourselves:¬†
‚ÄòWhat instructions could I give or what question could I ask so that the AI understands and gets me from A to B, solve a problem, or execute a task?‚Äô
This thinking will be more systemic, problem- and solution-orientated. 

I'm still so excited about what the future will hold for us. 

Steven Kotler recently wrote:¬†Humans, in flow, who can collaborate with each other, and with AI, are going to own the future. 

Agree?

By the way: I have a whitepaper about flow and respective research added to an open Perplexity space for free. DM me if you want access.

The result? Happier employees. 

The research here confirms that. What is more: AI breaks down silos. That‚Äôs another benefit.

The future belongs to AI augmented teams. 

What‚Äôs not to like?

Go, start. Now. Or risk being left behind.

text:
Like the early days of growing up, AI is uncharted territory for many people today.¬†The word AI has caused and continues to cause much unrest. 

I don't think the uncertainty comes only from the technological side.¬† It seems many companies might not be aware of the why, what, and how of AI.

‚û°Ô∏è The "why" of AI refers to my business strategy and why AI might influence my success
‚û°Ô∏è The "what" of AI refers to the type of validation process AI undergoes to create a business-case out of a use-case
‚û°Ô∏è The "how" of AI refers to the process of change that needs to be well planned and executed 

So, where does uncertainty come from? Is it a lack of knowledge about the technology or how to anchor it sustainably in the company? 

In any case: We need to change that.

Any thoughts?

Warum l√§sst der Gro√üteil der Unternehmen die eigenen Mitarbeiter noch wie Anfang der 2000er arbeiten, w√§hrend die Konkurrenz auf GenAI mit RAG und RPA setzt?

Stellt euch vor, ihr habt zwei magische Helfer, SpeedyBot (RPA) und BrainBox (RAG) in eurem Unternehmen:
SpeedyBot ist wie ein super-schneller Roboter, der f√ºr euch die langweiligen Aufgaben am Computer erledigt. Wisst ihr, wie ihr manchmal hundert Mal das Gleiche anklicken oder abtippen m√ºsst? Der Roboter macht das f√ºr euch - blitzschnell und ohne Fehler! Und jetzt ist er sogar noch schlauer geworden: Er kann nicht nur einfache Listen lesen, sondern versteht auch komplizierte Dokumente, und davon ganz sch√∂n viele, fast so wie ein Mensch.
BrainBox ist wie ein Superhirn, das sich an ALLES erinnert, was es in eurem Unternehmen gibt. Stellt euch vor, ihr k√∂nntet jemanden fragen ‚ÄúWelche Expertise verl√§sst das Unternehmen in den n√§chsten 6 Monaten durch Ruhestand und wie k√∂nnen wir sie bewahren?‚Äù oder ‚ÄúWelche Muster erkennst du in unseren Top-10-Kundenprojekten der letzten 2 Jahre?‚Äù - und dieser Helfer findet die Antwort sofort! Es ist, als h√§ttet ihr das Wissen aller Kollegen gleichzeitig zur Hand.
Wenn diese beiden Helfer zusammenarbeiten, ist das wie ein Superhelden-Team: Einer wei√ü alles, und der andere setzt es superschnell um!

Klingt gut?

üí° Wenn wir RPA (Robotic Process Automation) und RAG (Retrieval Augmented Generation) mit GenAI verbinden, schaffen wir quasi einen perfekten Dreiklang: Wir denken und formulieren mit KI, RAG liefert das pr√§zise Wissen aus allen verf√ºgbaren Quellen, und RPA setzt (repititve) Tasks in konkrete Aktionen um.

‚úÖ Kollaboration ist die Grundlage f√ºr eine engagierte Mitarbeiterbasis, indem man die Vernetzung und Zusammenarbeit erleichtert. ‚ùó Besseres Engagement.

text:
+14.000 Teilnehmer! Und so gut, dass ich Werbung for free mache.

The Autonomous Innovation Summit von BOI (Board of Innovation)

Es gab jede Menge Insights, Highlights und Learnings. Was es aber auch gab, waren so gut wie keine deutschen Speaker. Stehen wir mal wieder nur am Spielfeldrand? Ich will das nicht. Mitten ins Spielgeschehen - daf√ºr baue ich aidocr auf. Ich behaupte mal (ganz frech) die gleiche Vision und Passion wie Surojit Chatterjee CEO von Ema Unlimited und Arvind Jain CEO von Glean zu haben - die in einem gro√üartigen Panel zu Agentic-AI und der Zukunft der Arbeit gesprochen haben. Und genau daher verstehe ich nicht, wieso man hierzulande nicht genauso inspiriert, neugierig und explorativ mit dieser Opportunit√§t einer ver√§nderten Arbeitswelt umgeht. Es ist ohnehin unumg√§nglich - warum also prokrastinieren? 

Die Welle kommt - mit Wucht. Und Legacy-Systeme sowie eingefahrene Strukturen m√∂gen heute noch wie Schutzw√§lle erscheinen. Doch Obacht, denn - und ich glaube viele sehen es nicht kommen - eine neue Generation von Unternehmen steht bereits in den Startl√∂chern. Und zwar AI-first - nicht als Buzzword - sondern als DNA. Ihr Wachstum... meist untersch√§tzt. Weil wir uns Exponentialit√§t nicht vorstellen k√∂nnen - bis der eigene Marktanteil erst St√ºck f√ºr St√ºck und dann ziemlich deutlich verloren geht. Disruption... kennt... keine... Grenzen!!

Und die kommende Welle macht vor nichts (keiner Industrie) Halt. Wer denkt in der Old-Economy, also Manufacturing, Construction, Energy und Co. kann KI nichts ausrichten? Weit gefehlt. Auch hier gibt es Tools, Prozesse, Strukturen - und Agentic-AI, Computer Vision und fortgeschrittene Robotik werden die Spielregeln auch hier neu schreiben.

Es geht jedoch nicht nur um Technologie. Die wahre Transformation findet wie immer in den K√∂pfen - und damit zuallererst auf Management-Ebene statt. KI ist nur der Katalysator, aber der Mensch bleibt der Architekt des Wandels. Und hier liegt die eigentliche Herausforderung. Die Zeit zu handeln ist nicht morgen. Sie ist jetzt. Wer die Transformation - nicht KI - auf die lange Bank schiebt, unterschreibt meines Erachtens sein eigenes Verfallsdatum. Aufwachen C-Level, Manager und Unternehmenslenker. Am Besten selbst beim n√§chsten Autonomous Innovation Summit reinschauen.

Congratulations, Philippe De Ridder, Vincent Pirenne, and the Team. Exceptional work - not only as self-marketing for BOI¬†(which is honestly well deserved) but for pushing the industry towards transformation.

ùüê. ùêÄùêÆùêü ùêéùêÆùê≠ùê©ùêÆùê≠ ùê§ùê®ùêßùê≥ùêûùêßùê≠ùê´ùê¢ùêûùê´ùêûùêß:
Um die Produktivit√§tsvorteile mit KI zu maximieren, sollten Organisationen den Output statt den Input belohnen. Es geht nicht darum wer wie viel mit KI arbeitet, sondern wie gut der Output ist und ob sich dieser an der KI Governance orientiert. Dazu bedarf es einem Upskilling der (zuk√ºnftigen) KI-Nutzer.

ùüë. ùêåùêûùêßùê¨ùêúùê°ùê•ùê¢ùêúùê°ùêû ùêÖùêöÃàùê°ùê¢ùê†ùê§ùêûùê¢ùê≠ùêûùêß ùêöùêÆùê¨ùêõùêöùêÆùêûùêß:
Die Zukunftssicherung der Belegschaft erfordert die Betonung von F√§higkeiten, die KI einfach nicht ersetzen kann, wie emotionale Intelligenz, Selbstreflexion aber auch Neugier. Es Mitarbeitern zu erm√∂glichen sich mehr auf den Ausbau der eigenen F√§higkeiten zu konzentrieren, macht die gesamte Organisation besser und die Menschen noch zufriedener.

ùüí. ùêÑùê±ùê©ùêûùê´ùê¢ùê¶ùêûùêßùê≠ùêû ùêûùê¢ùêßùêüùêÆÃàùê°ùê´ùêûùêß:
Eine Kultur des Experimentierens sollte gef√∂rdert werden, um schnell auf Ver√§nderungen zu reagieren und kontinuierlich zu lernen. Dies erm√∂glicht es Organisationen, neue Ideen zu testen und anzupassen, um wettbewerbsf√§hig zu bleiben. 

ùüì. ùêÑùê¢ùêß ùêåùê¢ùêßùêùùê¨ùêûùê≠ ùêüùêÆÃàùê´ ùêñùêöùêúùê°ùê¨ùê≠ùêÆùê¶ ùê∞ùêûùêúùê§ùêûùêß:
Um exponentielles Wachstum zu erreichen, ist es entscheidend, die Denkweise zu √§ndern und bereit zu sein, die Organisation neu zu erfinden. Dies erfordert die Bereitschaft, au√üerhalb der gewohnten Bahnen zu denken und sich auf transformative Ver√§nderungen einzulassen.

ùüî. ùêíùê≤ùê¨ùê≠ùêûùê¶ùê¢ùê¨ùêúùê° ùêÆÃàùêõùêûùê´ ùêùùê¢ùêû ùêûùê¢ùê†ùêûùêßùêûùêß ùêÜùê´ùêûùêßùê≥ùêûùêß ùê°ùê¢ùêßùêöùêÆùê¨ ùêùùêûùêßùê§ùêûùêß:
KI kann - je nach Art der L√∂sung - √ºber die eigenen Grenzen hinaus genutzt werden. Projekte und andere Formen der Interaktion k√∂nnen mit einer zentralen KI f√ºr alle Beteiligten (Lieferanten, Partner, Kunden und sonst. Stakeholder) zu einem kompletten √ñkosystem transformiert werden. 

ùüï. ùêäùê®ùê¨ùê≠ùêûùêß ùê¢ùê¶ ùêÅùê•ùê¢ùêúùê§ ùê°ùêöùêõùêûùêß:
Nur wenige Unternehmen haben sich bisher dar√ºber Gedanken gemacht, was die intensive Nutzung von KI eines jeden Mitarbeiters f√ºr die Gesamtkosten bedeutet. KI-Anbieter sollten daher auf ihre F√§higkeit der Kostenoptimierung bei den Tokens gepr√ºft werden, sonst gibt es ggf. ein b√∂ses Erwachen.

OpenAI hat das neue KI-Modell o1 ver√∂ffentlicht, das signifikante Verbesserungen in Geschwindigkeit, Vielseitigkeit und Pr√§zision bietet. Parallel dazu wurde das Premium-Abonnement ChatGPT Pro f√ºr 200 US-Dollar pro Monat vorgestellt, das unbegrenzten Zugang zur Pro-Version des Modells o1 bietet. Dieses richtet sich vor allem an professionelle Anwender wie Forscher, Ingenieure und Entwickler.

Das o1-Modell zeigt deutliche Fortschritte bei komplexen Aufgaben wie Mathematik, Programmierung und wissenschaftlichen Analysen. Die Halluzinationsrate wurde reduziert, w√§hrend die Genauigkeit, durch ‚ÄúChain-of-Thought‚Äù-Training, verbessert wurde.

Zwei Dinge sind hier wichtig: 
1. OpenAI erwartet f√ºr dieses Jahr Verluste in H√∂he von etwa f√ºnf Milliarden US-Dollar, w√§hrend die Einnahmen auf 3,7 Milliarden Dollar gesch√§tzt werden, was mit den massiven Trainingskosten zusammen h√§ngt.
2. Allein der Betrieb von ChatGPT kostet OpenAI Berichten zufolge bis zu 700.000 US-Dollar pro Tag. Bei intensiver Nutzung eines LLMs, dass mit einem Prompt auf alle Unternehmensdaten zugreift und bei tiefer Analyse und Ausgabe der Daten durchaus 100.000 Tokens pro Prompt verbraucht, kann man sich vorstellen, dass 20 Dollar p.M. niemals ausreichen, um ein profitables Unternehmen zu werden.

Otto ist ein echtes Vorbild in Sachen #Innovation. Und andere deutsche Unternehmen sollten genau hinsehen. Warum? Weil das Ergebnis von KI tats√§chlich mehr "Spa√ü bei der Arbeit" und eine "h√∂here Zufriedenheit" ist. 

Otto Group hat schon 2023 ein eigenes KI-Tool namens ogGPT entwickelt, das auf der ChatGPT-Technologie von OpenAI und dem Azure OpenAI Service von Microsoft basiert.

Das Tool wurde Ende September letzten Jahres f√ºr rund 26.000 Mitarbeitende im DACH-Raum eingef√ºhrt und in der ersten Woche nutzten bereits √ºber 4.200 Mitarbeiter*innen den KI-Assistenten, der auf das komplette Firmenwissen zugreift.

Ein solches System ist der einfachste einstieg in noch viel komplexere und zukunftsf√§higere Ans√§tze, die mit einer einzigen Applikation √ºber das gesamte Unternehmen umsetzbar sind. Ein sch√∂nes Beispiel, wie der Arbeitsplatz der Zukunft aussehen und eine #Transformation gelingen kann.

text:
ùêàùêß ùêùùê¢ùêûùê¨ùêûùê¶ ùêÄùê´ùê≠ùê¢ùê§ùêûùê• ùê¨ùê≠ùêûùêúùê§ùêûùêß ùêØùê¢ùêûùê•ùêû ùêÅùê®ùê≠ùê¨ùêúùê°ùêöùêüùê≠ùêûùêß...

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Die Verwaltung investiert in KI... sehr gut
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Man versteht, dass es durch den demografischen Wandel bald mehr als nur ein "kleines" Bottleneck gibt... besser sp√§t als nie
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Die Kooperation der Agentur f√ºr Arbeit ist mit einem deutschen KI-Unternehmen... Alternativlos auf lokaler Ebene
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Es gab schon erste PoCs... Vorbildlich, wobei man "Techplattform" mal pr√ºfen m√ºsste... so ein fertiges Frontend, bei dem was ich hier als Features lese, ist es sicher noch nicht...
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Fokus liegt auf repetitiven Aufgaben die die KI √ºbernimmt (Bearbeitung von Antr√§gen oder Bescheiden)... Gut, f√ºr die Arbeitsmoral der restlichen 65%
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Mitarbeiter k√∂nnen ihr Wissen an die KI weiter geben (Pharai Catch)... das ist super, macht alles aber auch komplexer (Fact-checking, etc.)
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Aleph Alpha h√§lt Llama3.1 in der Hinterhand, weil man um die eigenen Schw√§chen der Modelle wei√ü... nun denn
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Auf der Einen Seite sagt man, man m√∂chte kein diskriminierendes Verhalten der US Modelle, gleichzeitig aber hat man genau ein Solches als BackUp... Widerspr√ºchlich 
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Bis zu 19 Mio. in einem 4-Jahres Rahmenvertrag (macht ca. 40 Euro pro User pro Jahr) und da soll Dev, Tech, Training, Data Governance mit drin sein? ... Good Luck... f√ºr jeden Euro AI braucht es 2 Euro f√ºr Change
‚ñ∂Ô∏è Die Kooperation der Schwarz-Gruppe mit Aleph Alpha entsteht hier sicher auch, weil man mit 10% Anteilseigner an AA ist... aber gut, dass man f√ºr Cloud und AI dann zwei deutsche Pioniere nutzt...

Was wirklich wichtig zu verstehen ist: AI ist eine Reise, auf die man sich begibt. Denn die M√∂glichkeiten sind - Stand heute - schon unglaublich vielf√§ltig. Und der demografische Wandel, wie auch der Fachkr√§ftemangel per se, sollten die T√ºr f√ºr AI-Anwendungen weiter √∂ffnen. Das geht aber nur, wenn Unternehmen eine gewisse Vision f√ºr AI haben. Das sollte, auf der einen Seite nicht einzig Business-Case getrieben sein, auf der anderen Seite nicht nur von der AI-Excellence betrachtet werden. Die Integration ist wie das Prinzip von #Innovation zu verstehen. Es geht √ºberhaupt erst einmal darum, ein Mindset zu entwickeln (und ich komme mir schon bl√∂d vor "Mindset" zu schreiben, ist aber so). Eine Offenheit, Neugier, Bereitschaft zu Lernen, Fehlertolleranz, etc. - alles Bestandteile einer solchen Reise. Und ich sage bewusst nicht "Projekt", sondern Reise, die, wenn richtig erdacht und beschritten, n√§mlich "human-centred", die Art und Weise der Arbeit nachhaltig positiv ver√§ndern wird.
Da macht also die Arbeitsagentur, unterm Strich, ganz sch√∂n viel richtig.

Ich denke es fehlt - ob gro√ü oder klein - am richtigen Ansatz. Top-Down die Strategie vorgeben, Bottom-Up die Transformation anschieben. Und in der Mitte des Handelns dann bitte die richtigen Technologien ausw√§hlen.

Lasst uns √ºber Emotionen reden! 

Klar, KI ist das Thema der Stunde - vor allem mein Top-Thema in der Zusammenarbeit mit Kunden. Und gleichzeitig ist KI doch nur ein Spiegel, der uns in Zeiten des Wandels auf das blicken l√§sst, was wirklich zentral ist - der Mensch! 

Im Gegensatz zur KI haben wir Menschen Emotionen. Hei√üt 1:0 f√ºr uns. Den meisten Menschen ist allerdings der "richtige" Umgang mit Emotionen nicht sonderlich vertraut. Richtig hei√üt in diesem Kontext ein (selbst-)reflektierter Umgang mit den eigenen und ein emphatischer Umgang mit den Emotionen unserer Mitmenschen. 

Darum ging es auch am gestrigen Executive Summit des Premium Leaders Club in der traumhaften Dependance bei V-ZUG in Hamburg. Wer einzigartigen Service und luxuri√∂se K√ºchen genie√üen m√∂chte, sollte beim Gro√üen Burstah 1 einkehren. Es gibt auch tolle Kaltgetr√§nke!

Wir haben an diesem Abend Top-Executives zusammen gebracht und neben - nat√ºrlich KI - eben auch √ºber Emotionen gesprochen. Christoph F. Theile hat eine Keynote zu "Emotional Leadership Intelligence" gehalten. Mich hat das stark an meine Coachingzeit mit Profile Dynamics DACH erinnert. Menschen sind sich ihrer Werte und Muster h√§ufig nicht bewusst (daher ja unbewusste und unterbewusste Muster). Und so kommt es, dass unsere Emotionen genau diese Muster ans Tageslicht bringen. Wenn wir den Umgang mit Beidem aber nie gelernt haben, wie soll dann wirkliches, pers√∂nliches Wachstum entstehen? Ein sch√∂ner Ansatz in sich zu gehen und zu reflektieren "Was bedeutet dieser Impuls? Was hat das mit mir zu tun?"

Ich hatte jede Menge Spa√ü neue Unternehmer:innen kennen zu lernen, den Abend zu moderieren und den PLC, der mehr ist als ein "normales" Business-Netzwerk, zu vertreten. 

Danke an Florian Nowak f√ºr den tollen Abend und an Anri Coza / Marion Walter f√ºr die tollen Bilder und Eindr√ºcke, die festgehalten wurden. Und nat√ºrlich an meinen Pr√§sidiumskollegen Christian Bracke.

text:
Ich muss gestehen, ich bin mittlerweile gro√üer Fan von NIO.

Nicht nur, weil mein eigenes Auto kaputt ist und ich durch die Partnerschaft von NIO Deutschland und dem Premium Leaders Club schnell mit einer Monats-Subscription eines ET7 gerettet wurde.

Was genau bedeutet das: 

Community bezieht sich auf das aktive einbinden und nutzen der Gemeinschaft, also der Kunden und Interessenten, um am Markenerlebnis zu partizipieren. 

Engagement besteht u.a. aus Gamification, Anreizsystemen und Netzwerkeffekten, die f√ºr NIO aus den Engagementma√ünahmen entstehen.

Hei√üt?

Ich konnte heute aus dem wunderbaren Flagshipstore Hamburg heraus ein paar Video-Calls in meinem privaten Konfi (Eppendorf) machen‚Ä¶ Konnte mit meinen NIO Points aus der NIO App Kaffee und Co. kostenfrei bestellen und hatte ausnahmslos nicht nur freundliche sondern wirklich wertsch√§tzende Gespr√§che an jedem Mitarbeitertouchpoint. 

F√ºr mich wird hier, als innovatives Unternehmen, viel richtig gemacht. Es gibt auch noch viel zu verbessern. Aber auch das geh√∂rt zu einem ExO-Unternehmen! ‚ùïexperimentieren ‚ùïnach Lean-Startup und durch schnelles Lernen iterative Verbesserungen herbeif√ºhren. 

Ich empfinde das als ein sch√∂nes Beispiel welche Attribute ein junges Unternehmern (vor-)leben muss, um nachhaltig erfolgreich zu sein.

Aus meiner Sicht die Tatsache, dass man es √ºberhaupt anwendet. Daf√ºr muss man Wissen schnell abrufen k√∂nnen. F√ºr Unternehmen bedeutet dies, schnell auf Mitarbeiter:innen zugreifen zu k√∂nnen. 

ùêèùê´ùê®ùêõùê•ùêûùê¶: Wenn nun diese Personen mit so wertvollem Wissen nicht da sind? Wom√∂glich sind es Babyboomer die k√ºrzlich in Rente gegangen sind oder das alsbald vor sich haben. Oder es gibt andere Gr√ºnde, weshalb man nicht (mehr) auf diese Menschen zugreifen kann.

ùêáùê≤ùê©ùê®ùê≠ùê°ùêûùê¨ùêû: H√§ufig ist das Wissen irgendwo im Unternehmen verankert. Abgespeichert in unstrukturierten Daten. Und damit kann man sagen: Data is the new oil... wenn man denn nur darauf zugreifen k√∂nnte.

ùêãùê®Ãàùê¨ùêÆùêßùê†:¬†Hier kommt KI ins Spiel! Einfach aber effektiv mit dem AI-Knowledge-Assistant sprechen, der direkten Zugang zu allen internen Dokumenten und Daten hat, mit denen man dann sprechen kann. Hier nur 3 Beispiele:

‚ûî"Gib mir eine detaillierte Aufschl√ºsselung der Produktionskosten f√ºr die neue Fertigungslinie, einschlie√ülich Rohstoffkosten, Arbeitskosten und Gemeinkosten.‚Äù
‚ûî"Beschreibe die spezifischen Sicherheitsprotokolle und -verfahren, die bei der Wartung und Instandhaltung von Maschine (...) zu beachten sind.
Erstellen eine Schritt-f√ºr-Schritt-Anleitung zur Identifikation und L√∂sung h√§ufiger Ger√§test√∂rungen in der Produktionsanlage."¬†
‚ûî"Analysiere die Produktionsdaten aus dem Jahr 2023 und identifiziere etwaige Trends oder Anomalien. Bitte gib mir eine detaillierte Zusammenfassung der Erkenntnisse in einem strukturierten Format, einschlie√ülich Diagrammen. Die Zusammenfassung sollte 1000 W√∂rter nicht √ºberschreiten und sollte sich auf die wichtigsten Leistungsindikatoren wie Produktionsleistung, Qualit√§tskennzahlen und Ressourcennutzung konzentrieren."

Man muss nur die richtigen Daten finden, um dann die Prompts zu stellen. Hier ist noch mehr wissenswertes aus dem Bereich der KI.

Es ist nur eine Frage der Zeit, bis die B2C Anwendungen von OpenAI, Antrophic und Google aka GPT, Claude und Gemini auch innerhalb B2B an Bekanntheit gewinnen. Wie hier am Beispiel Gemini, wo man sich im Helathcare Bereich mit einem eigenen KI-Produkt versucht.
 
ü§ì Med Gemini kombiniert AI Reasoning-F√§higkeiten durch Self-Training und die Integration von Websuchen mit der Verarbeitung multimodaler Daten wie EKGs und Videos sowie der effizienten Verarbeitung langer Kontexte wie umfangreicher medizinischer Aufzeichnungen. Nat√ºrlich sollen damit Befunde und Patientendaten analysiert und interpretiert werden. 

‚òùüèªF√ºr einen erfolgreichen Einsatz von Med Gemini sind allerdings noch zus√§tzliche Anstrengungen erforderlich, wie die Anpassung an spezifische Use-Cases, die Gew√§hrleistung der Datensicherheit und ethischer Standards sowie die Integration in bestehende Systeme und Prozesse.

Stability AIs Emad Moustaque steps down as CEO. It follows a turbulent 12 months for the company‚Äôs leadership team which has seen it replace its CTO and lose a VP of product, a VP of engineering, a VP of R&D, a head of research and two large language model leads, according to news from Sifted.

Then, a couple of days ago, there was Inflection AI, making news as its co-founders, Mustafa Suleyman and Kar√©n Simonyan, will join Microsoft AI. Big deal, especially for Microsoft. 

And don‚Äôt forget Sam Altman's quick trip from OpenAI to Microsoft and back again.

It's all part of the big shuffle. 

As everything shifts, I‚Äôm left wondering about the future of AI for businesses and investments‚Ä¶

Is AI at a turning point already?

What‚Äôs the driving force behind? New ideas, ethical guidelines, or just climbing to the top?

What‚Äôs the impact for VCs for future investments?

And at the same time my perception shifts‚Ä¶starting to put things into perspective. It‚Äôs just a game of Thrones - as usual. Nothing to special‚Ä¶ most likely‚Ä¶

text:
Jensen Huang, CEO of NVIDIA, which produces the AI chips that are powering 80% of companies building AI, says coding is no longer something we need to learn. Is he right?

Well, the answer is always more complicated than it seems. 

Here's my answer: he's both right and wrong.

He's right in that we don't need to teach children Python or Java syntax as much as we needed to in the past. We can have AI-powered coding assistants correct issues, even code small programs just by talking to them in natural language (like we speak to each other).

But he is wrong if he was talking about teaching children computer science. 

Computer science and AI are a way of problem solving. 

Just like we didn't stop studying math when the calculator was invented, or will stop enjoying how to write poetry now that ChatGPT can write poems, we shouldn't stop learning how we can make computers think and solve grand challenges just because we have AI assistants. 

Huang is encouraging everyone to learn creative problem solving and I assert we should do it by all and any means available to us. Critical thinking, inter-disciplinary curriculums, problem solving, all require a set of tools and techniques, and computer science, statistics and AI are very much part of that toolkit as are personal AI assistants.

Ironically, the most effective method of learning may still be the centuries old Socratic approach, even as we race into tomorrow with AI.

What do you think about this?

-- The future awaits. Ayesha

WTF is RAG? C-Level aufgepasst‚Ä¶ 

GenAI ist komplex, hier ist aber ein super Artikel der aufzeigt, warum Unternehmen jetzt LLMs auf ihren internen Daten kosteng√ºnstig nutzen k√∂nnen.

Gro√üe Sprachmodelle (LLMs) revolutionieren zwar die Art und Weise, wie wir mit Daten arbeiten, doch die Kosten f√ºr das Unternehmensspezifische Training sind enorm. Klar, weniger bei SLMs (Small Language Models).

Aber zur√ºck zum Thema:
Hier kommt RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) ins Spiel. I know - viele Fremdworte.

RAG erm√∂glicht es LLMs, direkt auf die internen Daten zuzugreifen, ohne sie vorher teuer trainieren zu m√ºssen. Einfach per txt, pdf, xls, etc.

Die Vorteile?
Kein teures Training. Keine Komplexit√§t in der Softeare-Integration.

Daf√ºr:
Enorme Effizienzsteigerungen im Bereich Knowledge Management und neue M√∂glichkeiten der internen Automatisierung.

text:
Beyond the AI hype - there is an urgent call for action!

In the heart of the AI revolution, it's easy to get caught up in the bubble, believing that every company is on the brink of the next AI breakthrough.

The truth? While there's a surge of offerings and a constant buzz around AI, a significant gap exists between perception and reality. Many businesses are not as ready as they think, missing out on critical growth opportunities.

The rapid emergence of AI-fueled new market entrants is not just a warning sign for incumbents; it's a clear signal that the future belongs to those who embrace AI with curiosity, speed, a solid understanding, and well-defined goals. 

The risk? Companies that fail to adapt risk being left behind, or worse, displaced by those leveraging AI to drive exponential growth.

The era of AI is not a distant future; it's here, reshaping industries, redefining competition, and redrawing success maps. The time to move is now. Waiting on the sidelines is no longer an option.

Embrace AI, not as a buzzword, but as a strategic imperative to unlock your business's exponential growth potential. 

#AIRevolution #GrowthMindset #Innovation #ExponentialOrganization #FutureOfBusiness

Our marketing approach is to:

text:
We raised our $25M Series A just 6 months after our seed. Here are the four reasons why:

1. The market is moving fast. A lot of new players are entering and we need to ship amazing products fast if we want to win

2. We want to maintain our really strong momentum. A lot of startups lose their momentum and their velocity platesus if they sit in one funding stage for too long. Raising keeps the team excited, opens doors with bigger customers and builds brand awareness

3. We wanted to attract amazing talent (most senior leadership & great engineers don‚Äôt want to take a risk on a seed stage company)

4. We know what we need to build, it‚Äôs just a matter of executing. And to build our ambitious roadmap, we needed more talented people on the team

Every startup has its own pace. For Artisan, it‚Äôs moving relentlessly fast because we know we have an opportunity here and we don‚Äôt want to miss it 

For some, building a company bootstrapped is the right path. If you want to maintain full control of your company, choose your own pace and take dividends, don‚Äôt raise money. If you want to move extremely fast and build a generational company, raise at a regular cadence

And if you want to join us, apply here: artisan.co/careers

Or hire our AI BDR Ava (who works even faster than us üòâ) then get in touch: artisan.co/talk-to-sales

author_headline: Founder & CEO at Artisan ü¶Ñ | Building AI Employees | Hire Ava, Our AI BDR Artisan

text:
When Artisan launched its audacious ‚ÄúStop Hiring Humans‚Äù billboard campaign across San Francisco, it didn‚Äôt just catch eyes ‚Äî it ignited a firestorm. Designed to stand out in a sea of tech jargon, the intentionally provocative message positioned Artisan‚Äôs AI SDR, Ava, as the future of sales development. What started with a single misspelled billboard (‚ÄúStop Hirring Humans‚Äù) quickly snowballed into viral outrage, 35,000 Reddit, Inc. upvotes, media frenzy, and even death threats.

Despite the backlash, Artisan doubled down on the controversy, with CEO Jaspar Carmichael-Jack posting the campaign on r/mildlyinfuriating, sparking millions of impressions. ‚ÄúWe wanted to draw eyes and spark interest... while driving a bit of rage with the wider public,‚Äù Jaspar admitted. Their strategy worked ‚Äî Artisan was soon flooded with sales meetings, made headlines in top media houses and saw over $2M in new ARR.

Beyond the noise, the campaign paid off ‚Äî Artisan is now one of the fastest-growing AI companies by brand search, per Ahrefs. ‚Äú70% of the people I meet in San Francisco now know Artisan. Before it was 5%,‚Äù says Jaspar. Though the messaging stirred controversy, it struck gold with their actual audience: tech companies looking to automate grunt work, not replace humans entirely.
In the end, Artisan clarified: ‚ÄúThe truth is, we love humans.‚Äù The mission isn‚Äôt dystopia ‚Äî it‚Äôs about freeing humans from tedious tasks. Ava was built to take care of what people don‚Äôt want to do, not take their place. Bold, risky, and a little chaotic ‚Äî Artisan‚Äôs campaign is a masterclass in standing out in tech‚Äôs loudest city.

text:
Over the last few weeks, I‚Äôve had many first year MBAs reach out asking how I landed my in-semester internship at Artisan. So here‚Äôs my blueprint:

ùó¶ùòÅùóÆùóøùòÅ ùóØùòÜ ùóØùòÇùó∂ùóπùó±ùó∂ùóªùó¥ ùòÜùóºùòÇùóø ùóπùóºùóªùó¥ ùòÅùó≤ùóøùó∫ ùòÅùóµùó≤ùòÄùó∂ùòÄ
- Before any outreach, I asked myself: Where do I want to be in 5‚Äì7 years?
- My answer: Product x Vertical AI Agents. Even this broad vision helped me filter my search
- The path may not always be linear, and that‚Äôs okay. But try to build towards where you want to be

ùóôùó∂ùóªùó± ùòÄùòÅùóÆùóøùòÅùòÇùóΩùòÄ ùòÇùòÄùó∂ùóªùó¥ PitchBook
.. and apply filters that align with where you want to work
- Sector fit ‚Üí I focused on AI agents
- Recent funding rounds (announced <6 months ago) ‚Üí signals momentum and recruiting appetite
- Round size (>$8M) ‚Üí I leaned toward Seed and Series A startups that raised enough to offer a real runway and stability

ùó¶ùó≤ùóªùó± ùóüùó∂ùóªùó∏ùó≤ùó±ùóúùóª ùó∞ùóºùóªùóªùó≤ùó∞ùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùóøùó≤ùóæùòÇùó≤ùòÄùòÅùòÄ ùòÑùó∂ùòÅùóµ ùó∫ùó≤ùòÄùòÄùóÆùó¥ùó≤ùòÄ ùòÅùóµùóÆùòÅ ùòÄùó≤ùóπùóπ ùó¨ùó¢ùó®
- Everyone says ‚Äúdemonstrate where you can add value.‚Äù I found that‚Ä¶ unproductive
- Startups are chaotic! You‚Äôll never guess what‚Äôs top of mind for them
- So I focused on what I did know: my track record and my skills

ùóîùòÉùóºùó∂ùó± ùòÅùóµùó≤ ùòÅùó≤ùó∫ùóΩùòÅùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª ùòÅùóº ùòÅùóÆùó∏ùó≤ ùóºùóª ùòÇùóªùóΩùóÆùó∂ùó± ùó∂ùóªùòÅùó≤ùóøùóªùòÄùóµùó∂ùóΩùòÄ
- I have 5+ years of experience, and I value my time
- But more than that, if your time has no defined value, you risk being handed low leverage / low value work
- Tip for founders: I never had to chat about this with Jaspar Carmichael-Jack at Artisan. He led with a solid comp package - no posturing, no games! Told me so much about how he leads

There‚Äôs no one right way, but this worked for me!

Two years ago, I was building a company I wasn‚Äôt passionate about. I was always looking for what would be next, and felt unfulfilled

I knew I wanted to build a truly impactful company, and when I had the idea for Artisan, I knew it could be exactly that. There is a paradigm shift taking place in software which we are betting everything on - the move from unintelligent sprawling SaaS to AI-first, consolidated products

It wasn‚Äôt smooth sailing to begin with, I was turned down by over 100 investors when I first started raising (to be fair, we didn‚Äôt have a product...)

Then Oliver Jung took a bet on us and gave us our first check for $1.75M

We got into Y Combinator shortly after that, and it‚Äôs been an insane journey since then

In the past 12 months, we‚Äôve:
- Built Ava, the AI BDR - our flagship Artisan
- Closed hundreds of customers
- Reached $5M ARR
- Gone viral with 1B+ online impressions on our ‚ÄúStop Hiring Humans‚Äù shock marketing campaign
- Hired an incredible team, including our new CTO Ming Li

And we‚Äôre just getting started

We‚Äôre extremely excited to have Paul Hudson from Glade Brook Capital Partners LLC joining our board. Oliver introduced me to Paul last August and he, along with the wider Glade Brook team (Isabel Swope, Linda Guo), has been an invaluable resource to us. We‚Äôre also grateful to Y Combinator for their reinvestment and continued support, and especially our group partner Pete Koomen who has been there day and night to help with whatever the issue of the hour is

author_headline: SaaS Tech & Climate Obsessed Marketing & Business Development Executive | Fullstack Marketer | CMO | Revenue Marketing | Board Advisor

text:
AI SDR's & All-In-One solutions have two huge advantages over tools like Clay.

Convenience & Ease. üëá 

While I'll always say you should use Clay & you shoul create your own tech stack to suit your own needs...

There is no denying that these all-in-one solutions are getting better everyday.

Here's some examples:

a) Unify 

They're making the most of AI Agents, and will also source all types of first & 3rd party signals for you.

b) Common Room

Common Room replaces the need for Clay by sourcing intent data & performing deep prospect research you can use for your outbound campaigns.

c) lemlist

While not as powerful with finding signals, lemlist allows you to link your OpenAI key, allowing you to create AI Variables.

With their chrome extension you're also able to get some awesome data to feed to GPT.

d) Instantly.ai

With Instantly.ai will set-up your email infrastructure, meaning you can use their tool to identify you website vistors & outreach all in one place. (Plus they even have a CRM.)

e) Artisan

Now the most unique example is Artisan, where they'll do everything from beginning to end. From hunting for signals, sourcing prospects, crafting campaigns, and outreaching.

... Let's pause for a second, because while I'd still say you can use Clay and just a couple other tools to also achieve the same thing.

You can't deny the convenience of all-in-one platforms, and with the rate they're advancing at...

It's not completely out of the realm to say they might overtake tools such as Clay, through ease of use alone.

While I still think we're quite far from that point, I also don't think we're too far from this being reality. üëÄ 

What's your thoughts on AI SDR's and All-In-One platforms?

P.S. We're running a Webinar with Unify @ 5 PM CET today, if you have any thoughts about all-in-one platforms, feel free to join us live on Linkedin to discuss them with their CEO Austin Hughes directly. üòâ

author_headline: Founder @hpy | ex-Uber

text:
The most successful outbound sales campaigns don't pitch a product. At least, not right away

Our CS team has been working with 100s of customers using Artisan and have found that across the board, the top-performing campaigns are the ones that prioritize building a relationship with prospects, above all else

Our CSMs comes from top lead generation agencies and brings years of hands-on experience creating outbound campaigns for clients - we want to set all of our users up for the best chance of success 

And what they've found is one tactic that works really well is withholding the sell until the second or third message. Make the first message about offering the prospect something they want

A great example of this is hpy, a mental health platform designed to enhance the therapy experience. After testing a bunch of different outbound approaches, the campaign that outperformed all others was one inviting therapists to be guests on their podcast

In fact, they received so many high quality responses that they're struggling to keep up with demand!

Read more about hpy‚Äôs approach (and results) in our latest case study:

text:
A lot of CEOs are against remote work, but if you're only hiring in-person, you're limiting your talent pool, overpaying, and making your team less happy & more distracted

Take sales reps for example. They're one of the most critical functions in a company, but our sales team spend 6+ hours per day on calls

It makes no sense for them to come into an office and sit in a tiny call booth all day

The same goes for a bunch of other roles which can thrive in a remote environment

It goes without saying that some roles work best in an in-person setting. If it's job function that requires a lot of brainstorming work, constant alignment or fast iteration, being in the office makes sense

Remote and in-person both have their place in 2025. Just look at our AI BDR, Ava - she works fully remote, and it hasn't slowed her down at all üòâ

text:
A year ago, I moved to San Francisco on an O-1 Visa to build Artisan‚Äîhere's the good, the bad and the ugly

At the time, we had just gotten into Y Combinator's W24 batch. On my first day in SF, my suitcase with all of my belongings was stolen from a car (the true SF welcome...) and I was living in SOMA

I learned 2 important rules after that:
1) Don't leave things in cars
2) Don't live in SOMA

Everyone talks about SF as the place to build a startup, but when I first arrived, it felt too quiet & slow - like not enough was happening

At the end of YC, despite the YC Partners' advice against moving to New York, I had told the team that we were moving the Artisan HQ there

But then, I got it. That quiet is the best thing about SF. It gives you the space to build, undisturbed, surrounded by people obsessively doing the same. No distractions, no noise‚Äîjust execution

SF has a uniquely tech-forward mindset‚Äîit's the only place we could have pulled off our "Stop Hiring Humans" billboard campaign. It's the only place where everybody understands the startup ecosystem and AI

SF is a pretty monotonous and boring city, and that's why it's amazing. If you're building a B2B startup, there's no excuse to not be here

----------

Ready to automate your BDR team's workload? Hire Ava, our AI BDR: https://lnkd.in/eHudjMTA

text:
This is the deck we used to raise a $2.5M pre-seed before we got into Y Combinator 

I‚Äôve decided to share the deck we used to raise our pre-seed deck to try and help out some people earlier in their journey!

The deck kind of sucked in retrospect, but creating it made me think about what I ACTUALLY wanted to build with Artisan

Here's what I would have done differently:
- Calmed down with the roadmap (the deck says we're going to do everything immediately, which investors know is impossible)
- Had less slides
- Focused more on the initial product
- Not included a fundraising roadmap or round size

Our vision has evolved completely since I made this deck, but having that initial grounding was so important to be able to paint a story to investors and early hires

Pre-seed fundraising is a long and painful process. If you're planning on raising, be prepared to face 100s of no's before you get a yes. Just treat each meeting and rejection as a learning experience and keep on shipping product/growing MRR - you've got this ü´° 

Full deck: https://lnkd.in/dtruwWeU

text:
I spent the weekend at the Y Combinator AI retreat where predictions were made among hundreds of founders leading the next wave of AI - here‚Äôs what I learned:

1. There is a consensus that AGI is around the corner and everyone building startups is f%^*ed

In the next decade the only thing of value that companies will be able to build is status goods. Think art, fashion, etc. Anything where the value is intangible and not based on the resources that went into making it


2. A lot of jobs are going to either disappear or change dramatically

Companies are desperate to fill roles with software, and the technology is getting to a point of convergence where we will suddenly be able to do that with a LOT of roles. Our focus this year at Artisan is prioritizing the roles we want to focus on automating

3. Work 100 years ago vs now looks like playing games - it will likely be the same now vs in 100 years

If you took someone from 1925 and showed them what we do for ‚Äúwork‚Äù today, they‚Äôd say we have too much time and aren‚Äôt actually working. Some think the same situation will exist in 100 years - the work people will be doing will look like play to us now 

4. A lot of companies are building cool s*%t 

Being around 100s of founders building insanely cool products with AI was inspiring- there‚Äôs an avalanche of sci fi-esque technology coming our way in the next few years

author_headline: Founder & CEO at Artisan ü¶Ñ | Building AI Employees | Hire Ava, Our AI BDR Artisan

text:
Here‚Äôs what getting 1000s of death threats taught me about B2B SaaS

When we launched our "Stop Hiring Humans" campaign for our AI BDR Ava, along with getting 1000s of inbound leads, we also received flood of hate messages ‚Äì from (pretty funny) insults to death threats across Reddit, X, TikTok, Instagram, Threads and even through the inquiries form on our website

Here are a few takeaways the experience taught me:

1. Rage bait works in a B2B context
While the general public outside of the tech sphere hated our messaging, they amplified it to reach more sales leaders and founders who loved it

2. People who don't take risks don't win
The hardest thing about B2B marketing is cutting through the noise and creating a brand that people *actually* notice. Running a controversial ad campaign was a risk, but it paid off in $millions of pipeline

3. Listen to your team
While we were workshopping campaign messaging, we had a lot of ideas that never made it to the drawing board because they were vetoed by the team for being too boring or (believe it or not) even more controversial

4. Don't worry about people's opinions unless they're in your ICP
When building a product, as in life, not all criticism is constructive. Learn to filter the noise and focus on feedback that helps you grow as a company

5. Security is important
Be it cybersecurity, SOC2 Compliance or an actual bodyguard (you probably need all 3 if you're using controversial messaging)

What doesn't kill you makes your SaaS stronger

text:
As CEO at Artisan, I‚Äôm the only person who doesn‚Äôt have a college degree. Even though I didn‚Äôt go to college, you probably should

When I was 18, I moved to London and started my first company instead of going to university

Why?

Originally, I had my sights set on studying PPE at Oxford and then founding a company

But when I was 16, I realized that going to college was going to suck 4 years of my life from me - time that I could spend ACTUALLY building a company instead of preparing to build one

I dropped out of my maths class required to get into the Oxford PPE course and fully committed to spending the rest of my life building companies

I spent my last 2 years of high school doing the bare minimum in class. I was focused on building, including my first ‚Äúreal‚Äù company, Assist, an app for people to book home services services

I got special permission to use my laptop in class due to my ‚Äúslow handwriting‚Äù üòâ and would sit in the back of class working on my startup

I even tried to drop out of high school but my parents were not on board

So what ended up happening to my first company?

It was a total flop. In hindsight, my idea had zero potential and was set up for failure. But it taught me a lot that has helped me build Artisan today ‚Äì way more than a university degree could‚Äôve. I learned:

- How to fail fast, iterate, and learn
- What ideas are good and bad
- How to hire and fire people
- How to manage a team
- How running a company works

-----------

But ironically, I still think most people should go to university

The job market is tough and it‚Äôs nearly impossible to stand out

I‚Äôve never had a real job before, and realistically I probably couldn‚Äôt have gotten one

At Artisan, we get 1000s of job applications every day and one of the first things we do is filter by university/past company. It‚Äôs not ideal, but it‚Äôs the easiest way to filter through masses of candidates

Getting into any sought-after career path - apart from becoming a founder - is going to require a top college degree or a lot of grinding and luck

Going to a good university definitely isn‚Äôt the hallmark of an intelligent, capable person, but it‚Äôs a surefire way to identify people that are smart and hard-working

If you‚Äôre 100% sure you want to be a founder, don‚Äôt go to university. If you want to go down a traditional career path, then do

For founders, the 4 years could be better spent learning how to build companies

For traditional careers, the 4 years dedicated to getting a top degree will catalyze the rest of your working life

And if you have an idea that you‚Äôre sitting on, there is no better time than NOW to start your company

P.S. If you did CS at Stanford, MIT or Carnegie Mellon please DM me, we‚Äôre looking for talent üòâ

text:
We got to ~$3M ARR in 5 months with our AI BDR. Here‚Äôs how. 

I‚Äôve said before that winning as a startup comes down to 2 things:

1. Product
2. Distribution

We started with a pretty terrible strategy for both‚Ä¶

Our first product sucked - we followed the YC methodology of launching early and iterating. Our MVP didn‚Äôt work, the UI was terrible and features were lacking heavily

Though this was a painful process, it enabled us to iterate and build faster than we would have otherwise

We also had no brand awareness, no SEO and no GTM strategy (as you‚Äôd expect for a pre-seed startup)

We started with product-led growth, which was a terrible model for us ‚Äì users never finished onboarding, our ACV was too low, the time-to-value was too long, etc

Think hard about whether product-led is right for you or if you should be doing sales-led

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

We rebuilt our entire strategy to hit $3m ARR in a few months

Product:

We rebuilt everything and launched V2 of our AI BDR, Ava, in May. The relaunch had a completely new UI and features our users had been asking for. We did 100s of user interviews to understand what our users wanted, and built:

- Live lead research across LinkedIn, X, news and the web to create hyper-personalized emails and LI messages

- New data sources to complement our B2B data including E-Commerce and Local Business Data

- Magic Campaigns, so Ava can create your campaign messaging for you 
+ much more

We‚Äôre working on a huge release for V4 of Artisan in Q1, so stay tuned ü¶Ñ

Distribution:

We built an extremely robust GTM strategy, spanning:

- A comprehensive outbound strategy using Ava, our AI BDR
- Our SF ‚ÄúStop Hiring Humans‚Äù billboard campaign
- Our TechCrunch Disrupt sponsorship
- Ramped up SEO efforts
- Funding announcements combined with big brand pushes 

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

We‚Äôre now consistently closing ~$1M of ARR every month and will continue to double down our efforts on building the best product on the market & maintaining our position as a market leader in AI Sales & AI Employees

We have some VERY exciting new products beyond just outbound coming early next year ü§ì
