text:
2 months ago, I moved into the Artisan House with Jaspar Carmichael-Jack and Sam Stallings. Here‚Äôs what it‚Äôs been like living with my startup founders: 

1. We've built a deeper connection than we ever could in an office 

For most teams, being in-person is enough to create the bond that a startup thrives on. Living together takes that bond to another level

I had visited SF before, back when we worked out of an office in downtown. It was productive & I got to know the team better‚Äîbut it wasn‚Äôt until we started living together that we actually became friends 

2. We collaborate on everything 

Not just on GTM strategies or product roadmaps, but also on coordinating chores & keeping everything running smoothly. Our ability to work together to solve problems & resolve conflict is tested daily, like when our ceiling started leaking in the middle of the night...

3. Constant alignment/brainstorming

Ideas don‚Äôt wait for office hours. Some of our most productive discussions happen over dinner or right before bed - living together creates a continuous flow of creativity and problem-solving that traditional work environments can‚Äôt match

There have been so many significant events & last-minute decisions and having immediate access to each other has been crucial for executing effectively (like helping Sam choose an outfit the night before F1 üòÇ)

4. We trust each other a lot more

Living together removes any room for pretense.¬†You share wins, losses, and vulnerabilities, which strengthens both personal bonds and the company culture

This allows for an openness in communication that would take much longer to develop otherwise

---

Living with your team is definitely not for everyone ‚Äî and I wouldn't recommend it unless you think it can work well. But for us at least, it‚Äôs convinced us that with the right people, it can really amplify your output

The past few months have been a rollercoaster, and it's been a privilege to ride out both the highs and the lows together 

We've also flown out many of our employees (already 5 this month) for mini on-sites to experience the environment of living and working together

It's definitely expedited my own growth - by living in the same space as my team, I've learned a lot in a remarkably short period of time. There have been so many more opportunities to ask, learn, listen & ensure that what I'm doing is on the right track

(We're looking for more in-person employees to join our team in SF, so get in touch if you're interested: artisan.co/careers)

text:
A lot can change in a year. Last year at TechCrunch Disrupt, I was struggling to raise pre-seed funding for Artisan. This year we sponsored it ü§†

text:
Being Chief of Staff means doing whatever the company needs - and often, doing the things that no one else wants to do.

I‚Äôve just spent the past few days learning how to set up domains and configure mailboxes for 100s of our customers because our technical support person is on emergency leave.

It's been late nights of fielding dozens of support tickets and auditing every customer's account to make sure we're still providing the best support we can for every user. I‚Äôve had a crash course in MX, SPF, DKIM, etc records and while it's definitely not my strong suit, it's what's most important to jump on right now

This kind of mentality is important no matter what role you are in a startup - there will always be changing priorities and fires to put out. You want to build a team of people who can take on anything that the situation requires

You‚Äôll never build a successful early-stage team if everyone is only willing to do what‚Äôs in their job description and that‚Äôs it. 

That‚Äôs the great thing about the team at Artisan. No matter what role people are, they're always willing to lend a hand - our AEs help QA new platform features, our engineers give feedback on our graphic designs & everyone pitches in where they can

But we also celebrate hard work & recognize when people are going the extra mile - like Jaspar Carmichael-Jack & Sam Stallings surprising me with a cake yesterday üòÇ 

This is what will set us apart from all the other players in the space - a team that is willing to put in 110% where it‚Äôs needed & champion this spirit

Everything we‚Äôve achieved so far couldn‚Äôt have been done by one person. But together, we‚Äôve gotten to where we are today - $12m in funding, $1.8m in ARR & 90% MoM growth üöÄ

text:
Over 1,000 sales meetings have been booked since we announced or $11.5M Seed round in Forbes 2 days ago...

Here's how we catalyzed our fundraising news to reach millions of people:

1. Post on ALL channels
We get strong traction for our fundraising news on LinkedIn, X, Reddit (by doing AMAs) and Instagram. If you don't post it everywhere, you're missing our on eyes

2. Have a hook
Nobody cares about your fundraising news unless you can relate it to them and make it emotive. We focused on the AI Employees angle and how they inevitably will take jobs - something everybody have a visceral reaction to

3. Ask investors and employees to repost the news
Tag all of your investors, and contact every employee and stakeholder asking them to repost your news (specifically the post from the CEO's profile)

4. Getting coverage from the right outlets and have an embargo
Getting coverage in Forbes and VentureBeat made people care about what we were saying. We couldn't have done that without Day One Ventures and Tara Harandi-Zadeh who handled the entire PR process for us. They set an embargo to make sure all press coverage went out at the same time, going for the "surround sound effect

5. Post before your competitors
Find out if/when your closest competitors are announcing news and beat them to it

Our 5 awesome sales reps are all fully booked for the next 2 weeks, but if you want to find out why so many people are desperate to hire our AI BDR Ava, you can find time to chat with them at https://lnkd.in/d3zaVPVB (there might be a cancellation you can snag üëÄ )

text:
In 3 years there will be no human BDRs.

Ok maybe that's slightly dramatic but there will be significantly less. The role of a BDR has become increasingly automated, but until now, no technology could fully replicate what a human can do. That‚Äôs about to change

I've chatted with 100s of BDRs who are excited about Artisan. No BDRs actually want to be BDRs - they want to build human relationships in an AE role

And companies are ready to spend less on their BDR org. For reference, Ava (our AI BDR) costs 90%+ less than the equivalent human output

Traditionally, the BDR role consists of a series of extremely manual tasks:

Build a list of contacts from a B2B data provider
Verify their contact info
Look for personalizations across their LinkedIn, X, news, etc
Prospect through channels like email, phone, or social media
Follow up
Respond to objections
Book in meetings
Update CRM

Automation has been slowly eating away at the BDR‚Äôs role for a long time and we're approaching a fully autonomous AI BDR. By 2025, AI BDRs will be list building, prospecting, qualifying over the phone, objection handling, booking meetings, taking notes, and updating CRMs autonomously

Ava already automates 80% of a BDRs role, finding leads, collecting data on from dozens of sources to effectively personalize emails and LinkedIn messages at scale, and managing deliverability

None of our prospects that receive Ava‚Äôs emails even realize she‚Äôs AI. Ava ghostwrites on behalf of humans

Ava is changing the way sales orgs function. You can learn more at https://lnkd.in/dX2Jscxj

text:
Product-led growth almost killed our startup - don't let it kill yours.

We‚Äôre closing $100,000s of ARR for our AI SDR product every month since switching to a sales-led approach

When we launched our beta product in February of this year, we started with a self-serve model

The "product-led is best" narrative that exists in the startup world is frankly not right for most companies

To be successful with a product-led approach, you need:
- An easy-to-onboard product
- A service that is viable at a low cost
- A fast time-to-value

We don't have all of those things (and nor do most startups):

1. Our users need to deep dive their ICP and messaging to set up Ava, our AI SDR. It's much easier when they do this with a customer success manager (most people won't spend an hour doing something without somebody else keeping them accountable) 

2. To do outbound effectively, you need to do high volume and you need hands-on support - that isn't cheap. To see strong results, our users need to spend at least $1-2k/mo

3. With Artisan, you have to wait for your mailboxes to warm up and for Ava to find the right messaging to start seeing value, which can take a few weeks. That is way too long for a product-led motion

If you're running a startup, ask yourself if your product meets those 3 criteria. If it doesn't, you should probably be sales-led

After we switched to sales-led a few months ago, our growth exploded

I talked about this last week at Product Hunt x Hexus‚Äô panel on GTM for PLG vs SLG companies

If you're interesting in hiring Ava and seeing what she can do as your AI SDR, you can chat with our amazing new sales team at https://lnkd.in/d3zaVPVB

text:
I'm turning 23 today, which makes me the youngest employee at Artisan as CEO ü§†

I‚Äôve always been obsessed with companies. I started my first ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù when I was 7 (a candy store in my bedroom, as seen in the below pic‚Ä¶)

Fast forward to a decade later, and I made the decision not to go to university and instead to start an app for booking cleaners & errand runners called Assist. 

The app failed for many reasons (classic tar pit idea with horrible unit economics, operational overhead and my lack of experience), but I learned an insane amount about how not to start/run a company

Through that failed startup and the relatively successful GTM agency I started after (both of which were during the years I would have otherwise been at college), I learned more than I ever could have in a degree

I started Artisan using all of those learnings last year when I was 21, and since then, we‚Äôve:
- Done Y Combinator
- Raised the biggest seed round of any YC company in our batch
- Closed over $1M in ARR
- Built an amazing, mission-driven team
- Continuously executed on our mission of building a trillion-dollar company

A few key learnings I would share with anyone, but especially young people are:
- Be confident. Confidence when starting and leading a company will help you get the best talent, investors, etc
- Don‚Äôt be afraid to create your own path. If school isn‚Äôt right for you, don‚Äôt go
- Just start. If you want to build a company, do it. The longer you wait, the less you learn. Stop procrastinating
- Educate yourself. There‚Äôs an insane amount of resources available (YC‚Äôs YouTube channel, startup books, etc) 
- Don‚Äôt give up, but be adaptive. Don‚Äôt continue to do something that clearly isn‚Äôt going to work, but give it your absolute best shot. If it‚Äôs clear it won‚Äôt work, pivot your strategy


If you want something, go get it

text:
Since I founded Artisan less than a year ago, we have shipped product, grown revenue, and built a functioning company faster than nearly any other startup founded at the same time. The only reason we‚Äôre able to move so fast is because of our relentless focus on execution. 

Execution is more important than anything else - a great strategy is nothing if isn‚Äôt actioned. We have strong processes in place to maintain our execution flow:

1. We create a quarterly strategy which is the cornerstone of everything we do - it covers every function within the company and lays out KPIs, goals and deliverables

2. We then break our strategy down into clear, categorized line item tasks of every required input to achieve the outlined goals and deliverables 

3. Each task and business function has a point person assigned. Strategies and tasks are nothing without accountability 

4. Tasks are prioritized based on size, impact and priority and then put into sprints in our project management software

5. We have a weekly accountability sync to make sure everyone has the required resources to execute

If your startup doesn‚Äôt have exceptional processes around execution, you‚Äôre never going to succeed. I‚Äôve put together an execution processes document the details how to get your execution machine humming - comment below if you‚Äôd like me to send it across to you

(We will be sending our GTM channel breakdown to those who requested it next Tuesday. The team are making some edits to perfect it after receiving 100s of requests!)

Artisan Sales and Ava, our AI BDR already replace and automate the entire outbound sales stack, and we have some insane product releases coming over the next few months. Want to know what Ava can do today? Head to https://lnkd.in/eAJ28nnS

text:
Trying to build a unicorn without a mission-driven cuture is setting yourself up for failure. So we got a hacker house.

We've rented a house in SF and some of our team have now moved in together. We got a huge billboard of Ava (our AI BDR) outside our window, so she can work with us too! 

We've been flying out our remote employees for in-person sprints. 5 of our team have already come to work with us in person, and it's led to some of the most productive weeks we've had.

In the span of a few weeks, we've:
- Built our strategy for the remainder of 2024
- Started laying the groundwork for our next Artisan üëÄ
- Mapped out our V4 sales product roadmap
- Done an in-person engineering sprint
- Gotten closer as a team

Building culture among a remote team can be difficult, and it‚Äôs something I‚Äôm learning more about and getting better at every day. 

A few of our early learning with remote/hybrid culture have led to us doing the following:

- A weekly All Hands that reiterates our mission, aligns the team and celebrates wins 

- Developing 6 core company principles which we encourage everyone to live by, centered around how we interact with others, operate, and treat our customers

- Clearly defining our mission. Everyone on the team knows we‚Äôre building a $100bn company and redefining the broken software landscape

- Only having the best people. Our team are extraordinary talented, work hard and seek perfection. We hold that bar with new additions  

- Making Slack fun! Our Slack is full of custom emojis and key stats are sent to different channels daily. We try to keep the ‚Äúoffice door knock‚Äù vibe by heavily using huddles

And as we rapidly grow Artisan, we're looking for insanely talented people to help us build the next paradigm of software - with consolidation and automation at the core of our mission. We're looking for passionate builders who want to pave the way for the next Industrial Revolution.

If that excites you, get in touch: http://artisan.co/careers

author_headline: 6,433 followers

text:
Artisan has just closed over $700k of ARR in 2 months. This is how I joined the founding team of a hyper-growth startup, without any relevant experience.

I spent a year applying to tech startups without getting any interviews or responses. I knew AI was a field I wanted to go into, but had no idea where to start. I only had ~1 year of experience working in PR, which would hardly make me stand out in a sea of applicants.

Here's what I did in that year, which finally landed me the CoS role at Artisan:

1. Created a list of AI startups that were fast growth, recently raised funding. I checked their job listings religiously.

2. Went to local networking events for founders and startups.

3. Checked the YC job board daily.

4. Used AI in every part of my life and read up on it constantly.

5. Reached out to people I thought were interesting on LinkedIn for coffee chats & insights into the industry.

6. Applied to every open listing that I was remotely interested in.

In December 2023, I got an interview with ElevenLabs. It was the first sign since I started my job hunt that someone was interested. The interviews went well, but as a Series A company, they were looking for someone with way more experience. I was crushed.

In January, I applied to Artisan via their careers form (artisan.co/careers), not expecting to hear back. The next day, Jaspar Carmichael-Jack messaged me to chat.

Here's what I did during the interview process that landed me the job:

1. Phrased my background to justify every step of my journey. I studied English at Oxford (talent for storytelling), went into PR (business operations interest), then moved from healthcare to tech (wanted to contribute to tech's global impact).

2. Was extremely responsive & hard working. I left Saturday plans early for a follow-up interview, spent all of Sunday on my interview task, and worked trial evenings until 12am, after my usual 9 to 5.

3. Excelled at a tough task. Because I lacked experience, I was given a mammoth task to create a website strategy for Artisan's next product launch. I had no idea where to start. GPT was my consultant through the whole process, helping me create a framework from which to work from.

4. Showed confidence in the value I COULD bring, despite my non-traditional background.

Experience shouldn't matter in hiring. Look for intelligence, resourcefulness, scrappiness - qualities for thriving in fast-paced environments. Artisan took a chance on me, which paid off through my rapid growth and dedication.

Build these qualities:
- Resourcefulness
- An insane work ethic
- Perseverance
- Confidence in your value

 and you'll catch someone's eye soon.

I've created a full doc on how to land the job you want. Comment below & I'll share it with you!

text:
We've closed ~$700k of ARR within 2 months as a seed stage startup.

Most startups fail at our stage because they can‚Äôt build enough traction to sustain long-term growth.

Why?

Traditional growth channels are dying - startups are burning cash, time, and morale by chasing ghosts.

We've cracked the code by building a lead gen machine that delivers ~50 qualified leads every day.

Here's how we did it:

1. Building a product that people want

It doesn't matter how great your marketing is - if no one needs/wants what you're building, you won't close any deals

We ask the right questions in user interviews & sales calls, and feed those insights directly to our roadmap. Our AI BDR Ava is 1% of what our future product is going to be

2. Creating engaging content on LinkedIn

Founder and thought leadership content is our secret weapon

Sharing our journey & wins is a huge channel for us. It's gotten us 1000s of leads and 10s of investors

Awareness spreads like wildfire (and it‚Äôs completely free)

3. Using Ava, our own outbound engine

A strong flow of leads are generated by our AI BDR product, Ava

In-depth personalization is key for getting responses from leads, and we're launching a huge update to take this to the next level in a few weeks - learn more about Ava at https://lnkd.in/eAJ28nnS

4. Tapping into the YC network

We're the leading outbound product in the YC ecosystem, and have YC companies turning to us every day to support building their outbound demand generation engine. If you're an early-stage founder with a B2B product with category-leading potential, apply to YC

5. Exploring a number of GTM channels

We've tested too many GTM channels to list here (SEO, blog content, influencer,  press, events, etc) and have learned a lot about what works/doesn't work for early stage B2B SaaS companies. If you want me to send you a breakdown of our analysis of different channels, leave a comment below

Great content + diversity of GTM channels + amazing product = Startup growth on steroids.

Our approach proves that with the right strategy, seed-stage startups can achieve remarkable results in a short time.
